avalancheActivity.highlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow are to be assessed with care and prudence.
avalancheActivity.comment:
The wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on very steep shady slopes at intermediate and high altitudes. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The wind slabs are covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise.
Avalanches can also penetrate deep layers and reach large size in isolated cases.
Maintaining distances between individuals and one-at-a-time descents are recommended.

snowpackStructure.comment: The new snow of the weekend is bonding only slowly with the old snowpack. Faceted weak layers exist deeper in the old snowpack in particular on shady slopes.

avalancheActivity.highlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution.
avalancheActivity.comment:
The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant and generally at intermediate and high altitudes. The avalanches can in isolated cases reach medium size.
The wind slabs are covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise.

Careful route selection and spacing between individuals are recommended.

snowpackStructure.comment: Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. Faceted weak layers exist deeper in the old snowpack on shady slopes.

avalancheActivity.highlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution. The avalanche prone locations are covered with new snow and are therefore difficult to recognise.
avalancheActivity.comment: Wind slabs can as before be released, even by small loads in isolated cases and reach medium size. This applies especially in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain in particular above the tree line, and on very steep shady slopes. Here avalanches can be released in deep layers of the snowpack and reach large size in isolated cases.

snowpackStructure.comment: In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. Faceted weak layers exist deeper in the old snowpack above approximately 2400 m.
